intro: Pseudoliparis incurva, commonly known as the curled liparid, is a flowering plant native to certain regions of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodland areas. Due to its ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens, though it is more commonly found in the wild.
